text: richard russo was one of america's most
versatile literary men a best-selling
novelist who also has turned some of his
books like the pulitzer prize-winning
empire falls into screenplays that have
been successful movies he came to The
Times building recently and we talked
about his new novel that old Kate magic
and also about the impact writing
screenplays and being a teacher has had
on his fiction for me when I was
teaching especially the beginners when I
was when I was teaching them about how
to develop characters and I was teaching
about them about the nature of conflict
what kind of what kind of conflicts work
and what and how to and how to recognize
a conflict that's not working you can't
do that day in day out with beginners
without saying to yourself all right now
here I am 350 pages into a novel have I
blocked out the thing you know have I
how you can't you can't go over the
basics with beginners without without
thinking to yourself what about the
basics of this work that I'm presently
embarked upon screenwriting strangely
enough the knock on screenwriting often
is that when a novelist starts writing
screenplays that the novels themselves
become more like screenplays they become
more spare they become more rooted in
the present that less time is spent
describing the real physical world that
less time is spent on what characters
you're thinking because these are things
that movies don't do very well right
because the camera the camera and or the
camera does them and the writer doesn't
have to and so a writer you know an
expansive writer like say Richard Russa
write screenplays and sudden and
suddenly the books become more s'more
screenplay like this there's more
there's more white space there's there's
there's maybe less density to it the
exact opposite thing has happened to me
every time I write a screenplay and come
back to writing my novels my novels
become even more
they become more interior because it's
like it's like you're building something
and you're only allowed to use a hammer
and a saw you know and then you go back
to the novel and you can open up this
great big toolbox and you say look at
those Crescent wrenches oh my god aren't
they beautiful I can't wait to use the
crescent wrench again and so my novels
my novels have have become even more
novel like I think since since I started
writing screenplays your major novelists
you've taught fiction who are some of
the novelist's you look to for
inspiration are we talking about living
or dead either either well the people
the people that that made me the kind of
writer that I am are not only dead but
long dead Dickens for his great big
canvases the importance of minor
characters Twain for just how important
comedy was if you want to go to dark
places if you want to talk about as
Twain did racism and ignorance and
violence parts of the American character
that we kind of don't want to admit to
Steinbeck for tone I remember there was
just a revelation when I was reading a
cannery row and he had a line in it Dora
flood was a great woman a great big
woman with a taste for Niall green
evening dresses and I thought okay I
understand tone now I understand where
there where the writer stands in
relationship to the sentence that that
just that just came out he's there he's
he's hiding in that he's hiding in that
sentence somewhere it is his attitude
and it makes us feel comfortable that we
know who we're talking to and are these
some authors you then taught your
students or have them read oh you bet
you bet and you get to know them better
as you're reading them with your
students you then see new layers there's
nothing there's nothing I think that
that helps a writer to appreciate a
writer even the writer that he already
loves this teaching is teaching that
writer to students yeah thanks a lot
richard russo enjoyed it thank you
you
